p: About the inflammatory activity of L. album extracts, cannot be ignored a study in which the leaves of this herb have been used as a placebo to test the anti-inflammatory activity of U. dioica (stinging nettle) [ 127]. That study prompted from the observation that the sting of the common stinging nettle has long been used for self-treatment of arthritic pain. A randomized controlled double-blind crossover study in twenty-seven patients with osteoarthritic pain at the base of the thumb or index finger was performed to ascertain if the daily application of nettle leaves in the painful area brought relief. L. album leaves were chosen as a placebo since leaves are almost indistinguishable from stinging nettle leaves. It was remarkable that after a week of treatment the score reduction with U. dioica leaves was significantly greater than that with placebo ( L. album leaves).
